div.head: A LETTER FROM GIBRALTAR. DR TIBBLES' VI-COCOA
A CHEERFUL SHIP'S COMPANY SINCE USING VI-COCOA
Mr. W. CATERER, 3 Mess, H.M.S. "FORMIDABLE," Gibraltar, writes :––
div.p: "I have the pleasure of writing to you to express our opinion as regards to your valuable Vi-Cocoa. We have had rather arduous times since we left Portsmouth, a month ago, having had to coal ship four times, being mostly night work. Whilst in the collier shovelling and hauling bags about we have become very tired and languid, and when we get a little time to have our meals we have made a nice drop of Vi-Cocoa, which is both refreshing and nourishing, and when we turn to our work we seem as though we could carry on with our work for a much longer time without feeling fatigued. Of course we could not do so if we had not take, Vi-Cocoa.

We all use it in this mess everymorning, as we find it more sustaining than the ordinary ship's cocoa which the Service allows us. We have recommended it to all our shipmates. There is a lot of remarks passed by several of the ship's company about all our messmates being so bright and cheerful, and they ask us the reason as we all belong to what is called in this ship as the comical party and we tell them that Vi-Cocoa makes us like it, and they say they will give it a trial.
"You are at liberty to publish this letter of praise as you please."
You must have read the striking testimony that is being published daily respecting the merits of Vi-Cocoa. And yet you have not tried it. We advise you do so at once.

Dr. Tibbles' Vi-Cocoa can be obtained in 6d. tins from all grocers ; or the Proprietors will send you free a dainty smaple tin upon receipt of a postcard to 60 Bunhill Row, London. E.C. a sking them to do so.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Delegation Municipale a'est reunie le 30 mai 1905 a 4 h. p.m. sous la presidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli.
Presents: M. M. Benachi, Fenderl, Mansour Bey Youssef, Soliman Bey Abani, Dr. G. Valensin, G. Zervudachi, membres, W.P. Chataway, administrateur, L. Sedky Bey, secretaire.

Sur la proposition du Comite u Musee, la Delegation emet un avis favorable a certains travaux de nivellement a executer dans les terrains situes autour de la Colonne de Pompee et proposers a la Commission Municipale l'ouverture des credits necessaires a cet effet.
La Delegation decide que la demolition de la Tour des Romains sera effectuee en regie et que les pierres retirees de cette demolition seront vendues au fur et a mesure de leur extraction.
Elle prend connaissance d'un projet de reglement d'application de la taxe sure les voitureset bestiaux et decide de le soumettre a l'approbation de la Commission Municipale.
La Delegation adopte un projet d'instructions pour les archives municipales.
Elle renvoie au Comite des finances une nouvelle lettre de l'Egyptian Investment contenant des renseignements complementaires au sujet de son projet de construction de halles et marches.
De meme, elle renvoie au Comite des Finances de nouvelles propositions de M. Joseph au sujet de son projet de construction d'une jetee-promenade au Port-Est.
La Delegation decide d'affectuer le releve des rues de Ramleh et autorise la depense necessaire pour ce travail.

Elle est disposee a executer les travaux de prolongement de la route des parcs, au sud de l'ancien cimetiere israelite jusqu'au fort El Nahas, au cas ou le proprietaire interesse accepterait de contribuer a la depense pour moitie.

La Delegation delegue M. Chataway pour la representer au sein de la Commission institutee par le service des irrigations pour l'examen de la question de l'augmentation du nombre des ponts du canal Mahmoudieh.

Font egalement partie de cette Commission un delegue des importateurs, un delegue de la Produce Association, un delegue de l'Administration des Douanes, l'inspecteur du 3me cercle, et un delegue de l'Administration des Chemins de fer.
La Delegation autorise une depense de L.E. 200 pour le curage des puisards des egouts pendant l'ete.

Elle prend note d'une lettre ministerielle informant que le Gouvernement a pris en serieuse consideration les remarques f aites par la Municipalite au sujet des defectuosites du transport des animaux et qu'il a entrepris les demarches necessaires pour remedier a cet etat de choses.
La séance est levee a 7 h. ½ p.m.

div.head: Le transport des animaux
div.p: La Delegation Municipale ayant demande une note explicative a M. Piot, directeur de l'Abattoir du Mex,
1° Sur les defectuosites du transport des bestiaux et de leur debarquement ;
2. Sur l'insuffissance de la nourriture des animaux soit en cours de route, soit dans les parcs quarantenaires ;
3. Enfin sur l'interdiction d'abattre le betail aussitot arrive, M. Piot, a presente le rapport suivant a M l'Inspecteur sanitaire :––

p.hi: Defectuosites du transport et du debarquement.

div.p: Les animaux importes a Alexandrie sont transportes en general par des bateaux speciaux, dans lesquels les properietaires ne se preoccupent que d'une chose : faire penetrer le maximum d'animaux dans un endroit donne sans songer aux regles les plus elementaires de l'hygiene ; pour eux le betail est une merchandise que l'on doit pouvoir, a l'instar du coton, "presser" a volonte. Aussi, qu'arrive-t-il? C'est que ces malheureuses betes entassees dans la cale tres obscure, non aeree ou les soins les plus vulgaires de proprete font completement defaut, respirent un air vicie qui corrompt les muscles quand il n'occasionne pas d'accidents mortels.
On comprend que l'Administration soit a peu pres entierement desarmee ; les mesures de protection devraient etre prises au port expediteur.

Le mode de debarquement se pratique d'une facon scandaleuse : presque toujours les moutons sont attaches 6 on 7 ensemble par un membre posterieur et hisses de la cale a terre ou sur les maones ; quant aux boeufs ou buffles, une corde leur est passee autour de la tete a la base des cornes et ils sont descendus a quai de la meme maniere qu'une marchandise quelconque, balle de coton, sac de farine, etc.; bien peu d'animaux, sont regulierement debarques, c'est-a-dire avec une sorte de tablier passant sous la poitrine pour se replier sur le dos, d'ou un crochet permet a la grue d'operer convenablement le dechargement. La Municipalite subventionnant la Societe protectrice des animaux pourrait attirer son attention sur ce point qui est plus particulierement de sa competence.

Les animaux, pendant toute la duree de la traversee, au moins ceux de provenance syrienne, observent un jenue absolu; ni nourriture solide ou liquide; si bien que la mer etant agitee (le fait s'est presente il y a deux mois a peine) ces malheureuses betes sont obligees de faire de l'autophagie pendant une duree de 8 jours quelquefois, mais qui n'est jamais inferieure a 72 heures! Ici encore il est profondement regrettable que l'administration ne puisse efficacement intervenir ;les sanctions feraient completement defaut.
Mais ou l'on peut agir, je pense, c'est en obligeant les proprietaires a donner, dans les parcs quarantenaires, une ration d'entretien

suffisante ; on pourrait prier l'administration interessee de bien vouloir imposer une quantite de nourriture qu'on lui laisserait naturellement le soin de fixer elle-meme. Cette question avait ete soumise a son appreciation pendant le cours de l'annee 1900 sur la proposition de la Municipalite ; je pense qu'il y a lieu de revenir de nouveau a la charge.

p.hi: Sur l'interdiction d'abattre le betail aussitot son arrivee.

div.p: Les animaux ne peuvent etre abattus, d'apres les reglements actuels, que 48 heures apres leur arrivee ; ce laps de temps est absolument insuffisant pour permettre aux animaux de se refaire des fatigues d'un voyage aussi penible: quatre jours pleins devraient au moins etre exiges. Cette question est reglee par des accords internationaux que seul le gouvernment pourrait porter devant le Conseil quarantinaire.
Le animaux fractures ou incapables de se nourrir, dans un but humanitaire et pour leur eviter des souffrances inutiles, sont abattus immediatement.
(Signe) Piot

Le Municipalite a decide de transmettre cette note a S.E. le ministre de l'Interieur, en le priant de vouloir bien lui preter son appui aupres des autorites competentes pour faire cesser les abus signales.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Le marche se raffermit de plus en plus et reprend de l'animation.

Les changements indiquent de la hausse: Ainsi la Banque Nationale monte de 27 ½ a 27 5/8 acheteurs l'ancienne emission et de 26 ¼ a 26 3/8 la nouvelle; l'Agricole monte de meme de 13 7/16 a 13 ½ acheteurs, la Land Bank de 9 a 9 1/16 et l'Anglo-American Nile de 5 5/8 a 5 11/16.
Par contre la Banque d'Athene reactionne legerement de 123 ¼ a 123 et la Khedivial Mail de 4 ¼ a 4 1/8.
On achete l'Investment a 1 11/16, les Markets a 22/3 et la Salt and Soda a 33/9.
Il y a eu de nombreuses transactions en Agricole, environ 2000 titres, des paquests d'Investment, de la Banque Nationale. Le cours de l'Agricole a touche un moment 13 19/32.
La tendance est bonne.

div.head: OUR PARIS LETTER.
div.p: An article published in the "Lanterne" brings home to us the fact that, at the end of a few short months, M. Loubet's term of office as President of the French Republic will have expired. A little known man, M. Loubet's election came as a surprise to most Frenchmen, and only those moving in the inner circles of the political world could tell the story of the intrigues which led up to the choice of so unfancied an outsider. But well has it turned out for the Republic that such a selection was imposed, for during the six years that M. Loubet has dignified the high office of Chief of the State France has become stronger and more self-confident, and has regained much of the moral influence in the world's councils of which the disasters of "l'annee terrible" had deprived her. Cooler-headed and more patient than Carnot, utterly free from the ostentation of Felix Faure, M. Loubet has known how to reconcile conflicting political interests and close up the Republican ranks. When he entered the Elysee, France was in the throes of an agitation which threatened to end in civil war ; thanks to his choice and support of able and fearless Ministers, that danger is past and the Republic stands, for the first time in its history, on really solid foundations. M. Loubet has more than once expressed the keen delight with which he looks forward to the time when he may lay down the cares of office and again become a private citizen, and if he allows himself to be nominated for a second term, it will be because his friends have persuaded him that in such a course his duty to the country lies.

Rumour is again busy with the alleged approaching resignation of M. Delcasse. Such an event is, no doubt, possible ; but it seems reasonable to look for the most obvious explanation of the present revival of the report to the disappointment of the Socialists at their recent failure in the Chamber to score any points off Government over the question of French neutrality in the Far East. From the standpoint of French interests in Morocco, it is much to be hoped that M. Delcasse means to stick to his post. While there are rumours (apparently made in Germany) that the Moors have rejected all the proposals of the French Ambassador, the German Envoy has arrived at Fez, has had prompt audience of the Sultan, and has been very well received. Mr. Lowther has also arrived, and for the time being, the members of the various Missions appear to be exchanging the preliminary courtesies before proceeding to enter upon the diplomatic conflict which will make Fez one of the most interesting spots on the world's surface for the student of international affairs during the coming summer. As I have already remarked, this summer is likely to be a warm one at the Court of Sultan Abdul-Aziz.

In discussing the question of neutrality in the Far East, M. de Lanessan says in "Le Siecle" that the forbearance shown by the French Government with regard to the Russian Admiral during the last five or six months could not fail to arouse complaints and protests from Japan. "In fact, such has been the case, and we have been compelled to give them immediate satisfaction, and to own that we did wrong. Would it not have been wiser and better not to have exposed ourselves to such a humiliation? No cause of disagreement existed between Japan and France. Our relations with the Japanese in the Far East have always been excellent, as they always have been in Paris. Why, then, did we offend the interests and amour propre of a country with which it is to our great advantage to maintain only friendly relations? And all of this has happened, it must not be forgotten, because our diplomacy has never dared to speak in St. Petersburg in the only language which is fitting in France: that is, the language of a royal and faithful ally, but the language, at the same time, of a nation which is conscious of its own interests, of its power, and of its dignity."

Events in Morocco and the Far East have awakened public attention here to the need of a strong navy, and the "Temps" has opened its columns to correspondence on the subject. The most interesting letter yet received is signed by M. Edouard Lockroy, some time Minister of Marine. The letter is remarkably because it rejects many of the theories on which French naval engineers have worked for many years, and admits that the principle which has guided British naval constructors is sound. M. Lockroy points out that, owing to the rise of the United States and Japan as naval Powers, the old ideas, which has governed the designs of French warships, that future battles for supremacy on the seas must be fought out in European waters, is exploded, and that the limited range of action of French ships, due to their small coal capacity, unfits them for the duties they may be called upon to perform.

Very concisely M. Lockroy lays it dodwn that the foreign policy of the country necessitates a fleet with a wide range of action ; that strategy requires speed and tactics gun power. In order to combine these three essential elements, he argues, it is necessary to increase the tonnage and cost of vessels, and the country must be prepared to spend 40 millions of francs on a single ship if she would have a navy capable of holding its own in a modern sea fight. The ex-Minister of Marine then goes on to make some interesting comparisons between the cost of warship building in France and in other European countries. He finds that France pays more per ton for new construction than any other nation, and gets less for it in the way of speed and efficiency. For instance, the "Charlemagne", which displaces 4,000 tons less than the "Majestic", cost 2 millions of francs more to build. The amount paid in wages in England per ton displacement is one-tenth less than in France, though the workmen are better paid in the former country. There is a greater difference still in the cost of material, England paying four-tenths less than France per ton of displacement.

The passing of the bill for the separation of Church and State during the existence of the present Parliament becomes more and more improbable every day, as the interminable discussion on sub-section 4 drags out its weary length. At the present rate of progress the bill cannot be voted in time for it to be sent to the Senate before the commencement of the vacation in July, and when the Chambers meet again in October they will be fully occupied in dealing with the Budget for 1906, which must be voted before the dissolution in March next. The balance of public opinion is in favor of the measure, and deputies who owe their seats to Separatist votes dare not risk them by open opposition to the bill. But, as I have pointed out before, there is a curious unwillingness on the part of many members of Parliament to be responsible for its passing into law, and progress is delayed as much by professed supporters as by avowed opponents. Now, too, the intimate relations which are evidently being established between Germany and the Vatican have given pause to many, and people are asking themselves whether Germany is not already preparing to take the place of the eldest child of the Church, which France would vacate by tearing up the Concordat. It becomes necessary to answer the question –– Will French influence suffer in consequence? As a reply is not easy to find, the result will probably be that Church and State will not be separated during the existence of the current Parliament.

M. Combes and his sequestration law have left to the French Law Courts a heritage of litigation for which he and they little bargained. In sequestrating the property of the property of the monastic congregations, no account was taken of the position of those members who had taken with them private property on the understanding that their future was provided for in the common life of the body. Now they are deprived of that provision, and the question arises as to their rights. Among the brothers of the Christian schools alone, five hundred different suits for restitution have been entered, which would occupy one court for a year and a half at least. As it is probable that at least an equal number of such cases will arise in every congregation affected, the outlook seems to be little less than appalling.

There is no extravagance in the supposition that the recent sitting of the Academy of Medicine in Paris may turn out to be the most remarkable meeting in the history of medicine. For some time past, the most eminent bacteriologists have been devoting all their energies to the discovery of the microbe of a certain disease, which is hereditary beyond all other diseases, which simulates almost every known complaint, is the chief cause of nervous and arterial lesions, and is responsible for the infliction of more misery upon the guilty and upon the innocent than any other disorder which afflicts mankind. For long the bacillus eluded all research, but it has at last been tracked down and identified as spirochaete pallida, a long, pale, infinitesimal, and evenascent being which offers peculiar difficulties for the observer, both from its minuteness and from the fact that it is specifically refractory to staining for miscroscopic purposes. The identification is a triumph of bacteriological skill, and it is hard to over-estimate its possible results to the human race. The discovery of the microbe is not, as have unfortunately learned in the case of tubercolosis, always the same thing as the discovery of the anti-toxin, but is the first and greatest step in that direction, and that is no reason why the Schaudinn bacillus, as it is called after its discoverer, should prove more intractable than the bacilli of small-pox, anthrax, hydrophobia, diphtheria, and splenic fever. To conquer the disease which it produces would be not merely to relieve a vast amount of suffering, often cruelly undeserved, but to rescue humanity from the most degenerating influence to which it is subjected, and to deliver thousands yet
unborn from a curse which poisons the very springs of life.

Excessive competition being one of the roundabout ways to mutual understanding, Marseille and Genoa are beginning, after a long course of cut-throat tactics, to wonder whether a more comfortable live and let live policy could not be devised. Many are beginning to say aloud that accommodation is quite possible, and M. Meline, the leader of French Protectionists, is heading the movement in France. He urges that the two cities, laying aside their strife, should agree on proposals which their united pressure would compel the Governments of the two countries to accept. Such are the sweet uses of retaliation.

Not content with the Forty Immortals of the Palais Mazarin, France is now, it seems, to have another Academie Francaise, one devoted to the cult of "Le Sport." The first twenty members of the "Academie Sportive" have been elected by the readers of a motoring journal, and the elect will now proceed to co-opt another score of persons. The twenty already chosen are rather curious specimens of "Sport," as it is understood in the land whence our neighbours have borrowed the word. They include eight motorists, two balloonists, and a novelist. As to racing, hunting, shooting, cricket, football, running, rowing, swimming, tennis, or golf, they are not represented at all, so far. What the functions of the Sporting Immortals will be ; but then there are actually irreverent persons who fail to perceive the utility of even the wearers of the "palmes vertes" themselves. We shall watch the completion of the sacred number, and the development of their programme, with feelings of sportive interest.

The splendid reception given in Paris to a representative body of British medical men is a symptom not only of the sympathy of French people with all movements that make for the good of mankind but also of their disposition towards the people of Eugtand.
The "Figaro" gives a quite new rendering of "la veille chanson britannique" in its account of the dinner to the doctors in Paris.
"Et l'on s'est leve," runs the report, "de table aux sons de l'air cher aux etudiants d'Angleterre :––
"For he was a jolly good fellow
and to-day all of us,"
repris en choeur par toute la delegation anglaise."
As the writer goes on to remark, "Nous autres, les Francais, nous n'en connaissions guere les paroles.

div.head: THE NILE AS A COMMERCIAL RIVER
div.p: The Alexandria correspondent of the "Times" Engineering Supplement says that there is evidence that the question of fluvial navigation upon the Nile is beginning to engage the serious attention of engineers and public men in Egypt. Sir Hanbury Brown has recently, in an admirable series of papers, illustrated the more prominent defects of the Nile and its branches as commercial waterways. He has shown that the Government, in perfecting the irrigative power of the Nile, has to a large extent neglected the river's navigable resources. Nor does the situation of the Government, with its valuable possession of the State railways, allow it to view the Nile as anything but a formidable competitive route, likely at any moment to assume undesirable proportions. This being so, Nile development becomes a question principally of private enterprise, one, moreover, in which British capital and enterprise are largely interested, because they are bound sooner or later to be called upon to aid in the opening up the great waterway, if, indeed, they do not attempt it upon their own initiative. It is fitting, therefore, that private enterprise should be made acquainted with the early stages of the subject.

Quite recently in Cairo, at an interesting conference, M. Leroux, the president of the Societe des Sucreries et Raffineries d'Egypte, summed up the chief bearings of the case by saying that the efficiency of the Nile for commercial navigation would begin as soon as easy and unfailing communication was assured between the capital and the sea. This primary desideratum can only be secured by the remodelling and improvement of the main junction canals –– i.e., the Behera and the Mahmoudieh ––an operation which lies solely within the competence of the Government. The result would be to have a waterway navigable at all season for vessels of fair tonnage.

M. Leroux calculates the amount of merchandise that would pass the first year from and into Cairo alone at 2 ½ million tons ; but this estimate may be reckoned to be rather an under than an over statement of what might be expected. To cope with even this volume of traffic would necessitate extensive quayage space along the banks of the Nile in the neighbourhood of the Embabeh railway bridge. In fact a port, well equipped with modern appliances, and provided with spacious warehouses, would have to be created, together with a dock or docks roomy enough to berth river vessels and steamers of the largest dimensions.

Gradually, as traffic increased, it might reasonable be expected of the Government that the reaches of the Nile upstream of Cairo would be successively be rendered fit for navigation, until an unrivalled artery of communication stretched from Alexandria to Assouan, bearing all but a fraction of the entire agricultural produce of Upper and Lower Egypt.

Despite the disadvantages at present prevailing, two or three companies are alreading trading in the river transport of freight between Cairo and Alexandria. It needs but the provision of improved navigation to stimulate capital, calling into being busy wharves where there are now lifeless banks, and increased flotillas of steam cargo boats to superseded the unwieldy feluccas of a bygone age.

div.head: THE OLDEST TEMPLE IN THEBES
div.p: Mr. H. R. Hall, M.A., of the Egypt Exploration Fund, delivered an interesting lecture last week, in the lecture-room of the Society of Arts, London, on recent discoveries in Thebes. The lecture was illustrated by a series of lantern slides, and by articles found in the course of the excavations. Mr. Hall described a temple, the oldest in the district, which has just been brought to light. It dated from the Eleventh Dynasty, or about 2500 B.C., and was probably a funeral temple or an antechamber to the tomb of King Mentuhetep III. This tomb still remained undiscovered. Mr. Hall's description was extremely lucid, and gave eloquent testimony to the valuable work which the Egypt Exploration Fund is doing.

div.head: GAMBLING IN CORFU
div.p: The Prime Minister and Minister of the Interior of Greece, M. Th. P. Delyannis, has sent a telegram to the Prefect of Corfu, with reference to a scheme to create a gaming establishment in the island, informing him that as the realisation of such a scheme would necessarily bring serious developments (as Corfu would then be regarded as an international centre of gaming), the Greek Government considers it necessary to announce public beforehand that the establishment of a gambling-place in a Greek island, or in any other section of the Greek kingdom, would be repugnant to the conscience of the Greek people, and consequently neither the present nor any other Greek Government could even think of permitting or tolerating the existence of such a resort.

div.head: THE KAISER AND ENGLAND
div.p: The foreign editor of the "Revue de Paris," M. Victor Berard, publishes in its issue for May an interesting statement about the foreign policy of the German Emperor. We quote from the "Times" translation :–– "During the last ten years in which I have been professor at the Ecole Superieure de Marine, twenty or thirty of my pupils have repeated to me textually the same phrases, not dropped from the Imperial lips in private intercourse, but uttered with the emphasis of gesture in the circle of official representations. And always the Emperor expounded the imperious reasons necessitating a Franco-German "entente"…..The object was always a crusade either of the Continent against the United States or against yellow Asia. . . . .Always against something or some one. William II. undertook to federate the whole of Europe or a part of Europe, as a matter of fact –– his "hatred of England" being betrayed almost unconsciously in his most insignificant utterances –– Continental Europe."

div.head: ALGERIAN FRENCH
div.p: The following specimen of French as she is wrote reaches us from an Algiers paper. It describes a "garden party" given by the Governor-General : –– "Dans les splendides jardins anglais du gubernatorial "Palace" tout le high-life Algerois, toute la gentry s'etaient donne rendez-vous jeudi dernier. Les tramways de Mustapha superieur etaient pris d'assaut. Des buffets abondamment pourvus de plum-cake, de plum-puddins, de sherry-brandy, de sodas, de whisky furent devalises par les invites assoiffes et affames. Shoking! On dansa le boston ; mais le cake-walk fut exclu de cette fete tres smart et tout-a-fait reussie.

div.head: WOMAN AND MARRIAGE
div.p: "Woman," a woman's paper informs us, "is being convinced by degrees that marriage does not of iteself alone guarantee happiness." If you wish to see women throughly insulted go to the papers written for women. Where else would anyone dare to imply that woman was sufficiently idoitic to believe that marriage "of itself alone" guaranteed anything? The oracle continues : "She is learning by experience and observation that it is possible to be as happy without man's love as with it, if she can only think so." This seems a sort of Christian Science. You are as happy with the tooth-ache as without it, "if you can only think so." Even this is it with the love of man.
